attributes.title: Resisting “Broken Windows:” The causal effect of neighborhood disorder on political participation.

q1.value: Resisting “Broken Windows:” The causal effect of neighborhood disorder on political participation.

q5.value: We would like to thank Ryan Enos for provision of the voterfile data.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study leverages the emergency closing Long Island bridge in Boston Harbor, and the subsequent transfer of the homeless shelter and drug abuse facilities on the island to the Boston Medical Center area, to test the response of neighborhood residents to increased neighborhood disorder. Since the increase in neighborhood disorder was not a function of changing behavior of long-time neighborhood residents, but an invasion of the underclass from elsewhere in the city of Boston, we expect long-time neighborhood residents to be mobilized to protect their neighborhood. As a result, we expect their political participation to increase in response to the threat of neighborhood disorder. We further expect that neighborhood residents will feel the most threatened, and be the most spurred to political action, the closer they live to the source of neighborhood change. These hypotheses build on theories of political action in response to the desire for neighborhood improvement, and in response to changes in social geography, driven by threat response or NIMBY (Not In My Back Yard) attitudes.

q16.value: Exposure to increased neighborhood disorder, disorder that is increased by an influx of individuals from outside the community, will spur neighborhood political participation in response to the threat. Therefore, after the closing of the Long Island bridge, turnout should increase for voters who live proximate to the sites that saw a sharp increase in neighborhood disorder. The level of perceived threat and experienced disorder should be a function of proximity to the affected sites. As such, we anticipate that the treatment effect should be smaller for voters who live farther away from the sites. The quantities of interest we will be estimating are the average treatment effect of changes in turnout for three sets of elections (and the analogous feasible average treatment effect when matching is employed). This quantity represents, on average, changes in individual-level voter turnout change for those proximate to sites, in comparison to those further away from the sites.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we leverage individual level, geo-coded voting and public service request data to compare political participation from before and after the Long Island bridge closing. Through a difference in differences design, we compare temporal changes in political behavior between city residents who live close to the affected sites to those who live further away from the sites. Through this analysis we can test theories of political participation in response to local neighborhood changes, and attitudinal responses to exposure to poverty, crime, and neighborhood disorder.

q19.value: The sample is the number of voters in the city of Boston (N= 368,768)

attributes.title: Choice, Cognition, and Affect during the 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic
attributes.description:
The 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic is an unprecedented event inducing similarly-unprecedented levels of chronic, sustained stress and anxiety on a global scale; thus, the downstream effects of these affective responses on behavior are currently unknown. Previous characterizations of stress and its effects on cognitive performance, using lab inductions of acute stress and measurements of naturally-occurring chronic stress, are arguably of a different magnitude than the intense stress and anxiety induced by the pandemic, due to its life-or-death, quickly changing, pervasive and uncontrollable nature. The current moment is thus a unique opportunity to understand how intense, real-world stress and anxiety influence fundamental cognitive processes, including the ability to flexibly allocate mental resources using cognitive control, and the evaluation of risk and basic construction of value. Understanding how these cognitive abilities and behaviors shift during a pandemic could provide crucial, missing, and foundational information about the human mind and brain under severe stress. Characterizing such effects could prove crucial to the development of strategies, interventions, and policies that address, account for, and mitigate changes in individuals’ choices and cognitive performance in response to intense, real-life, stressors. 

To study this, we are conducting an experiment on Pavlovia, where U.S.-based participants complete both laboratory-quality behavioral tasks and self-report surveys. In particular, participants will complete a risky decision-making task (Sokol-Hessner et al., 2016) dissociating and quantifying risk attitudes, loss aversion, choice consistency, and context effects, and a cognitive control task measuring proactive versus reactive control (an AX-CPT paradigm; adapted from Gonthier et al., 2016). Performance in both of these tasks has been shown to shift in response to affective and stress influences (e.g., risky decision-making: Sokol-Hessner et al., 2009, 2015a, 2015b, 2016; AX-CPT: Chiew & Braver, 2013, 2014; Yang, Miskovich, & Larson, 2018), but these effects have typically been characterized in the laboratory using experimentally-induced manipulations of affect and stress. In the present study, we propose to examine shifts in decision-making and controlled performance as a function of pandemic-related stress, which we will characterize using a combination of subjective self-report measures and objective measures indexing pandemic progression using epidemiological data. In addition to behavioral task performance, we will obtain self-reported measures of state and trait anxiety, perceived stress, subjective loneliness, and perceptions of the pandemic and its personal risk. Demographic measures including age, gender identity, socio-economic status, race, ethnicity, and state and county location will also be measured.

Importantly, we will recruit a sample stratified by state and associated pandemic progression (measured using epidemiological data from state and federal public health agencies) and propose to collect participant data in two phases. In Phase 1, we will collect data every 24 hours over a 20-day period, enabling us to examine whether and how task performance and psychological measures shift across participants as the pandemic progresses over time. Pending funding, Phase 2 will commence immediately after Phase 1 (i.e., 20 days after commencing data collection in Phase 1). Phase 1 participants will be invited to re-enroll in the study and complete task and self-report measures again. Re-enrolled participants will take part in Phase 2 following their participation in Phase 1 as closely as possible (i.e., if a participant was recruited and participated on Day 4 of Phase 1, we will aim to re-enroll them and have them participate on Day 4 of Phase 2).

q1.value: Kimberly Sarah Chiew, Peter Sokol-Hessner, Hayley R Brooks, Anne Mobley Butler, Chelsey Pan

q2.value:
We will test how pandemic-related stress, as indexed by self-report measures of anxiety, stress and loneliness, as well as pandemic-related events like changes in the number of confirmed infections or deaths from state and federal databases, are associated with changes in choice and cognitive performance. Specifically, we will test the following predictions. 

Risky decision-making: We will test the hypothesis that pandemic-related stress will be associated with no net effect on risk attitudes (risk aversion or risk seeking) but decreased loss aversion. We expect no net effect on risk aversion on the basis of mixed prior findings. On the one hand, increased risk aversion was found following the chronic administration of cortisol over 8 days (Kandasamy et al 2014), while another, larger study measuring chronic levels of naturally occurring cortisol on a scale of months found no consistent change (Chumbley et al, 2014). The literature on the effects of acute stress on risk aversion is also mixed, with laboratory studies finding that risk aversion increased (Porcelli & Delgado, 2009), decreased (Pabst et al 2013), and did not change (Sokol-Hessner et al 2016) as a function of acute stress responses. We expect decreased loss aversion on the basis of prior findings indicating that higher chronic levels of cortisol on a scale of months are linked with reduced loss aversion (Chumbley et al, 2014). Our task will additionally enable us to separate any possible effects of chronic, pandemic-related stress on risk attitudes and loss aversion from those on choice consistency. Finally, in our recent research, we have identified strong effects of previous outcomes on subsequent risk-taking that cannot immediately be explained by learning (Brooks & Sokol-Hessner, in revision). Because these findings are so recent, it is not yet known how stress may alter such integrative processes. We will thus explore the effects of stress on temporal context effects in risky monetary decision-making by examining whether the effects of past outcomes on risk taking vary as a function of stress. 

AX-CPT performance: We will test the hypothesis that pandemic-related stress, as indexed by both pandemic progression and self-report measures of anxiety, stress, and loneliness, will be associated with a decrease in proactive cognitive control (poorer AY trial performance) in the AX-CPT. This hypothesis is formulated on the basis of prior findings of declining context maintenance and proactive control as a function of both anxiety (Fales et al., 2008; Yang, Miskovich, & Larson, 2018) and anticipation of punishment (Braver et al., 2009). Importantly, there are two possible hypotheses we will test regarding reactive control under stress on the basis of prior evidence. While a number of studies (including Braver et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2018) demonstrated an increase in reactive control concurrent with a decrease in proactive control, these modes of control have been argued to operate independently instead of being necessarily inversely correlated (Chiew & Braver, 2017). Given additional observations that cognitive flexibility, which has been argued as analogous to reactive control, decreases under acute, laboratory-induced stress manipulations (Plessow et al., 2011), we will thus also test the hypothesis that reactive control (indexed by BX trial performance) will decline in addition to proactive control.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a within-subjects design. All participants will take part in a risky decision-making task where behavioral performance will be analyzed following prior work (Sokol-Hessner et al., 2016; Brooks & Sokol-Hessner, in revision) examining risky decision-making as a function of pandemic stress and prior context. All participants will also take part in a cognitive control task (the AX-CPT) enabling separate metrics of proactive and reactive control, which will be analyzed as a function of pandemic stress.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Using Pavlovia.org, we will collect data from a U.S.-based online sample over a 20-day period (Phase 1) followed by a second 20-day period during which time Phase 1 participants are invited to participate a second time (Phase 2). 

Importantly, we will collect data from a sample stratified by pandemic progression. Using information about COVID-19 case numbers in each state (obtained from usafacts.org), we will assign each state to either the first, second, third, or fourth quartile of states in terms of number of COVID-19 cases on the day of data collection commencement. An equal number of participants from each quartile will be recruited each day for 20 days in Aim 1. We will invite Aim 1 participants to take part again in Aim 2, with their recruitment in Aim 2 timed to follow Aim 1 as closely as possible (i.e., if a participant was recruited and participated on Day 4 of Phase 1, we will aim to re-enroll them and have them participate on Day 4 of Phase 2).

q11.value: We will recruit 560 participants into Phase 1 of the study (28 participants, or 7 participants per quartile, taking part on each day of the study for 20 days) and attempt to recruit as many Phase 1 participants as possible to return for Phase 2.

q12.value: Using G*Power3, we estimated that to detect a small effect size (f^2 = .02) with 90% power and alpha = .05 in a linear multiple regression with four predictors (two-tailed), we need a sample of 528 participants. We based our estimates on the assumption of a small effect given lack of precedent for this event in the existing stress and cognition literature.

q13.value: We aim to collect N=28 per day for 20 days in Phase 1 of the study and will re-enroll as many of our Phase 1 participants into Phase 2 as possible. Given the time-sensitive nature of the study (20 days in Phase 1 and 20 days in Phase 2), we will stop recruiting participants each day when the day time-window is over.

question.value:
Measured variables to be used in confirmatory analyses: 

Risky decision making task: Probability of selecting the risky option, computation model parameters (e.g. loss aversion, risk attitudes, choice consistency, decision bias, context effects).
AX-CPT task: accuracy rates and reaction times as a function of task condition (AX, AY, BX, BY trials) 
Pandemic progression: for each participant, calculated on the basis of state and county location (number of cases and number of deaths on the day of participation)
State and trait anxiety (measured using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) 
Perceived stress (measured using the Perceived Stress Scale)
Loneliness (measured using the UCLA Loneliness Scale) 

Measured variables to be used in exploratory analyses: 

Social contact questions: 

How many people did you physically see on an average day in January? "Physically see" is defined as getting within 10 feet of someone without any barriers between you and them.
On an average day in January, how many people were you interacting with (rating each of the following individually): in person; by video chat; by phone; by email; by text; by social media
How many people do you physically see on an average day now? "Physically see" is defined as getting within 10 feet of someone without any barriers between you and them.
On an average day now, how many people are you interacting with (rating each of the following individually): in person; by video chat; by phone; by email; by text; by social media

Perception of and behaviors toward the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic: 

Please rate the overall level of risk to you personally that you perceive from the COVID-19 pandemic. (1-9 scale; 1=none, 9=extreme) 
How much of a threat do you think COVID-19 (coronavirus) is? (1-7 scale; 1=not a threat at all, 7 = extremely threatening)
 How likely do you think it is that you yourself will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic? (1-7 scale; 1=extremely unlikely, 7=extremely likely)
How likely do you think it is that someone you know will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic? (1-7 scale; 1=extremely unlikely, 7=extremely likely)
Are there currently any cases of COVID-19 in the city where you live? (Yes, No, Not sure) 
Has anyone you know personally tested positive for coronavirus? (Yes, No, Not sure)
Are you currently social/physical distancing? (Staying home whenever possible, avoiding contact with others, maintaining at least 6 feet of distance from anyone you aren’t living with.) (Yes, Somewhat, No) 
How long have you been social distancing? Please input your answer in days. (open field) 

Demographic information (gender, race, ethnicity, age, state and county location) 
Socioeconomic status (measured with questions about family income, parents’ education level, current occupation, current income, worries about finances, qualifying for financial aid, etc.)

Risky decision making. Our analysis approach will focus on fitting participants’ choices of risky or safe options as a function of the values present on the current and recent trials. Specifically, we will leverage advanced Bayesian hierarchical linear and nonlinear modeling procedures (i.e. mixed-effects logistic linear regression using the packages lme4 and/or brms in R; sampling-based estimation of prospect-theory inspired nonlinear models using Markov-Chain Monte Carlo [MCMC] procedures in Stan) to separately and simultaneously account for multiple different cognitive processes underlying risky decision-making, including risk attitudes (feelings about chance), loss aversion (relative weight of losses versus gains), choice consistency (randomness in the decision process), decision bias (a value-independent bias to choose risky or safe outcomes). This approach will also enable us to pool data across participants while still allowing individuals to vary, thus maximizing our statistical power. We will correlate individual differences measures of perceived stress, state or trait anxiety, loneliness, and/or pandemic perception, as well as objective measures of pandemic progression like the number of confirmed infections or deaths with the parameter estimates across people, as well as enter these variables directly as covariates into the linear and non-linear models. 

AX-CPT. Accuracy rates and median correct reaction times for each trial condition (AX, AY, BX, BX) will be calculated and examined using repeated-measures ANOVA. An inverse efficiency measure combining both accuracy and reaction time (Bruyer & Brysbaert, 2011) will also be calculated for each trial condition and examined using parallel ANOVA analyses. Significant effects will be followed up with pairwise comparisons.  

We will also compute a proactive index, a composite behavioral variable measuring relative tendency toward proactive control (following Chiew & Braver, 2014), for the same three metrics of behavior: accuracy rates, reaction times, and inverse efficiency measures. The proactive index will be used as an outcome variable in multiple regression analyses with pandemic progression (number of cases and number of deaths), state anxiety, trait anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness as outcome predictors.

q19.value:
Risky decision-making: For linear model fits, we will use conventional statistical thresholds of p < 0.05 when evaluating beta estimates. For nonlinear computational models, we will use likelihood ratio tests to evaluate components of maximum likelihood-estimated models with a standard p value of p < 0.05, and we will use 95% confidence intervals with the Markov-Chain Monte-Carlo (MCMC) samples produced by Bayesian estimation methods.

AX-CPT: For evaluating results of ANOVA and multiple regression analyses, we will use conventional statistical thresholds of p < .05 and two-tailed tests.

q20.value: Data will be excluded if participants fail attention checks or fail to understand behavioral task instructions. Task performance <= 3 standard deviations below mean performance may be considered evidence of failure to understand the task and constitute grounds for exclusion. AX-CPT task trials with reaction times under 200ms will be excluded from analysis.

q21.value: Missing data will be excluded from analyses. Sample sizes for each analysis will be specified accordingly in the text of the eventual manuscript.

q22.value:
Social contact questions: We will examine how individual differences in social contact (and differences between January and current social contact) are related to measures of pandemic progression, anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness. We will also examine whether individual differences in social contact predict experimental task performance above and beyond the measures used in confirmatory analyses using hierarchical regression. 

Perception of and behaviors toward the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic: We will examine how individual differences in COVID-19 perceptions and behaviors are related to measures of pandemic progression, anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness. We will also examine whether individual differences in these perceptions and behaviors predict experimental task performance above and beyond the measures used in confirmatory analyses using hierarchical regression. 

Demographic and socioeconomic status questions: We will examine how demographic factors and socioeconomic status are related to measures of experimental task performance, stress, anxiety and loneliness. We will also examine whether demographic factors and socioeconomic status moderate the influence of pandemic progression, stress, anxiety, and loneliness on task performance. 

Affective state as a mediator of pandemic progression’s effect on choice and cognitive performance: We will conduct mediation analyses to examine whether the relationship between pandemic progression and task performance outcomes is mediated by measures of stress, anxiety, depression, social contact, and perceptions/behaviors towards the COVID-19 pandemic.

The proactive index will be used as an outcome variable in multiple regression analyses with pandemic progression (number of cases and number of deaths), state anxiety, trait anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness as outcome predictors.

attributes.title: Clinician Scientist in Rehabilitation and Medicine: A Scoping Review Protocol
attributes.description:
ABSTRACT
Background: Clinician scientists play a role in bridging the gap between research and practice. However, the role of a clinician scientist is less established for healthcare professionals in rehabilitation in comparison to medicine and nursing. Purpose: The purpose of this scoping review is to explore the different roles and models of a clinician scientist in rehabilitation and compare this to medicine and nursing. Methods: This review was structured according to the Arksey and O’Malley framework for scoping reviews. A literature search will be conducted from the following databases: EMBASE, MEDLINE, AMED and Web of Science, as well as a grey literature search from MacSphere, ProQuest, DuckDuckGo and Google. This scoping review will look at all publications that describe the role of a clinician scientist in rehabilitation or in medicine, across all health care settings. Researchers will review titles and abstracts independently, in groups of two, followed by a review of full articles. Data will be extracted from all sources and pooled together in a table with common themes to synthesize the results. The authors will provide a summary of the information in relation to the research question of this scoping review. Conclusion: The results of this scoping review will help identify the current roles and models that exist for a clinician scientist in rehabilitation, in comparison to medicine.

q1.value: Demonstrating Novel Forms of Crossmodal Correspondence

q3.value: Though the Bouba-Kiki effect, and crossmodal correspondences in general, have been popularized in the last two decades, greater research is still needed in this area. How many combinations of correspondences are there? Can the Bouba-Kiki paradigm be used to demosntrate other forms of correspondence?

q4.value:
(1) Participants will be more likely to label the round figure “Bouba” and the angular figure “Kiki” on the sound-form task.  
(2) Consistent trends will be observed across the personality-form, smell-form, the second sound-form, temperature-form, affect-form, and taste-form matching tasks. 
(3) Participants who score congruent on the sound-form task will be more likely to score similarly to the majority trends identified in hypothesis two.  
(4, exploratory) Participants who score higher on postformal thought will demonstrate a greater number of crossmodal correspondences.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Nonexperimental, cross-sectional, correlational design. Examining crossmodal correspondences and their relationship to postformal thought.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participation in this study will be offered as an option to fulfill research participation requirements in introductory psychology courses. Participants will be recruited through the SONA Research Participation System. They will complete the Bouba-Kiki Matching task, the PTS, and demographic questions (age, ethnicity, gender). Upon completion, they will be granted class credit.

q13.value: Our target sample size is at least 67 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100 participants to compensate for potential missing data.

q14.value: For the primary hypothesis, a power analysis using G*Power suggested that at least 31 participants are required to detect a large effect with an alpha level of .05 and power of .80 (using the effect size observed by Bremner et al., 2013). However, for our fourth hypothesis, a power analysis suggested that at least 67 participants are required to detect a medium effect with an alpha level of .05 and power of .80.

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped at 100 participants.

question.value:
Bouba-Kiki Matching: Following the “Kiki-Bouba” paradigm used by Köhler (1929) and Ramachandran and Hubbard (2001), participants will be presented with two closed figures (from Kim, 2020; see appendix). Each time they are presented with the two figures, they will be asked to categorize each into one of two categories (Bouba or Kiki, extroverted or introverted, etc.; see appendix for a list of pairings). Participants’ responses will be classified as congruent or incongruent. For example, pairing the rounded figure with the name “Kiki” would be labeled as an incongruent response. These figures will be presented under the narrative premise that they are aliens to be interacted with. The purpose of this is to both engage participants and distract them from potential demand characteristics. Once participants have completed this task, they will be asked: “If you had been given a neutral option, rather than being forced to choose between two options, would you have chosen that?” The purpose of this question is to assess participants’ discomfort with the forced-choice design. 

Postformal Thought: This will be measured using the Postformal Thought Scale (PTS; Cartwright et al., 2009). The PTS consists of 10 items. A sample item will be “I tend to see several causes connected with any event.” Participants will rate their agreement with each item on a 6-point Likert-type scale. Cartwright and colleagues successfully demonstrated convergent validity and reliability. Internal consistency was adequate (𝛼 = .63).
The postformal thought scores will be combined into a single mean score.

Data will be cleaned and coded (see appendix for the codebook). Distribution properties will be examined for continuous variables using skewness, kurtosis, and a Shapiro-Wilk test. Missing data will be handled according to Schlomer and colleagues (2010) recommendations: rate of missing data will be reported, item-level missing data rates will be reported in supplementary materials, and pairwise deletion will be used to handle missing cases. Descriptive statistics will be run on all demographic variables. Reliability coefficients (Cronbach’s α and McDonald’s ω) will be calculated for the PTS. Both coefficients will be used, given the increasing disfavor with Cronbach’s α (see McNeish, 2018). 

One-way chi-squared tests will be run on each of the Bouba-Kiki tasks to examine the first and second hypotheses. Participants will be split into two groups according to their congruent or incongruent responses to the traditional sound-form task. For those matching tasks that displayed trends, as identified in the second hypothesis, a sum score of congruent responses will be given to each participant. An independent samples t-test will be run to test the third hypothesis using these sum scores. 

Exploratory tests will be run. A Pearson correlation coefficient will be estimated between PTS mean scores and the sum of congruent responses to test the fourth hypothesis. Lastly, chi-square tests will be run to test for any ethnicity or gender differences.

q20.value:
Codebook
“ID” = ID value for participant
“Sex” = sex of participant (1 = male)
“Age” = age, in years, of participant
“Ethnicity” = ethnicity of participant 
“Sound_form” = response to the traditional sound-form Bouba-Kiki matching task (1 = Bouba matched with round figure, 0 = Bouba matched with angular figure)
“Personality_form” = response to the personality-form matching task (1 = introverted matched with the round figure, 0 = introverted matched with the angular figure)
“Smell_form” = response to the smell-form matching task (1 = lavender matched with the round figure, 0 = lavender matched with the angular figure)
“Pitch_form” = response to the pitch-form matching task (1 = lower pitch matched with the round figure, 0 = higher pitch matched with the angular figure)
“Temperature_form” = response to the temperature-form matching task (1 = hot matched with the round figure, 0 = cold matched with the angular figure)
“Affect_form” = response to the affect-form matching task (1 = sad matched with the round figure, 0 = sad matched with the angular figure)
“Taste_form” = response to the taste-form matching task (1 = bitter matched with the round figure, 0 = bitter matched with the angular)
“PTS_1” = score on item 1 of the PTS
“PTS_2” = score on item 2 of the PTS
“PTS_3” = score on item 3 of the PTS
“PTS_4” = score on item 4 of the PTS
“PTS_5” = score on item 5 of the PTS
“PTS_6” = score on item 6 of the PTS
“PTS_7” = score on item 7 of the PTS
“PTS_8” = score on item 8 of the PTS
“PTS_9” = score on item 9 of the PTS
“PTS_10” = score on item 10 of the PTS
“PTS_Mean” = mean score of the 10 items of the PTS
“Cong_Res” = number of congruent responses, as identified in hypothesis two
“Choice” = response to the question regarding opinion on forced-choice design

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for all analyses.

q23.value: Missing data will be handled with pairwise deletion.

q24.value: We will test for relationships between the demographic variables and our primary variables (Matching, PTS).

attributes.title: Interoceptive Isolation - Studying Interoceptive Experiences in a Global Pandemic
attributes.description: A pre-registered investigation of how self-isolation during the COVID-19 pandemic influences mood, bodily self-experience, and well-being.

q2.value:
Subjective stress, negative well-being, negative mood/affect, and the intensity of interoceptive experience will all linearly increase as a function of isolation duration. 

Subjective interoceptive attention will decrease as a function of days since “country lockdown” for clinicians working directly with COVID-19 patients. I.e. The sign of the slope will be opposite than for people in isolation.

The magnitude of these increases will correlate with trait-level interoceptive belief, as measured by MIAI-2 subscales.

Intolerance of Uncertainty will significantly moderate the relationship of subjective anxiety/stress/mood and interoceptive attention. I.e, the more you are intolerant of uncertainty, the more you try to control the situation by attending to the body, and this results in increased negative affect. 

The magnitude and degree of shift in expectations about the crisis (e.g., its duration and severity) will correlate with intolerance of uncertainty, and will predict mood volatility.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will apply a repeated measures observational design. Participants recruited from the web and online participant pools will be invited to complete 6 total surveys, once every 72 hours, over a period of 15 days. These will include measures of mood, affect, anxiety, depression, and interoceptive experience. Additionally, they will fill out demographic and situational information about themselves and their experience of the COVID-19 pandemic. Semi-daily measures of mood and interoceptive experience will be sampled by short online rating scales, delivered once every 72 hours.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All measurements will be conducted via the Aarhus University Redcap system, which has been previously approved by the Danish Data Protection Act and is fully GDPR compliant. Participants will receive a sign-up link directing them to an initial survey which will provide information about the study and require informed consent prior to participating. Following the completion of the first measure, they will receive automated emails every 72 hours, at the same time as they completed the first survey session. These emails will contain a link directing them to the survey measures for that day. A total of 6 measurements will be obtained, with the majority occurring on session 1 (day 1) and session 6 (day 16). A total of 145 measures will be collected at time 1, 127 at time 6, and 32 at times 2-5. See figure 1 for overview.

q11.value: New participants will be admitted into the study for a total period of 30 days from the initial start date. We will attempt to recruit as many participants as possible within this time period. Based on our power analysis, we hope to recruit a minimum of 350 participants. However, given the inherently exploratory nature of this project, the multivariate design, and the implications for public health, we believe it is important to obtain as much data as possible. No data will be collected following the 30 day period, and we will not base any data collection decisions on results or analyses.

q12.value: We intend to analyze multivariate correlations between longitudinal changes in mood, affect, well-being, and interoceptive belief as a function of days in isolation. Our partially repeated measures design will improve power to detect the effect of days in isolation on these measures. However, we also want to build models expressing covariation between these effects, and individual differences in interoceptive belief, demographic variables, and respective isolation experience. Our chosen pre-existing measures have all been shown to have reasonably high consistency (e.g., Chronbachs alpha > 0.70) in norming samples. Although power-analysis for an exploratory design such as this is not obvious, we would like to be able detect significant effects explaining at least 5% or more of shared variance between our measures. According to the Gpower tool, to detect a coefficient of determination of 0.05, i.e. an effect size of r = 0.22, with 95% at a p < 0.01 alpha criterion in a two-tailed test requires 342 participants in a simple bivariate correlation model.

q13.value: Our stopping rule is that we will stop collecting data (admitting new participants) after 30 days of data collection.

question.value: Please see the attached file, index of tested variables, for a complete list plus specific question texts.

data.name: Index of Tested Variables - Body Isolation Project.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Index of Tested Variables - Body Isolation Project.pdf

question.value:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable. 

Mental Health 
Summary scores of well-being (WHO-5), depression (PHQ-9), anxiety (STAI-7), the sense of agency (Rotter-12), and intolerance of uncertainty will be measured by summing individual item responses according to their published standards. Paired sample t-tests will be used to compare time 1 vs time 2 scores for each of these measures.  Additionally, Pearson correlations between paired differences on each measure and the total time in isolation (continuous variable) will be calculated. A bonferroni corrected alpha threshold of p < 0.005 will be used to assess statistical significance for these 10 comparisons. 

Experience with Social Distancing
One-way repeated measures ANOVAs will be used to analyze linear increase or decreases in how much people report worrying about the crisis (C4), the strength of their social distancing measures (C5), and their mental and physical isolation tolerance (ES2 & ES3). The F-test on the main effect of time will be used to evaluate any significant linear change on these variables, alpha criterion p < 0.01. Exploratory correlations between these measures and the previously described pre vs post shifts in mental health scores will be calculated; this exploratory analysis will use an alpha criterion P < 0.005 to assess significance. 

Timepoint 1 Experience Sampling Data
Initial responses to the mood and interoceptive experience sampling data will be analyzed using an exploratory factor analysis approach. MIES data will be reduced using exploratory factor analysis, with varimax factor rotation and parallel analysis to determine the optimally fitting  number of factors. For PANAS-SF, we will constrain the factors to two total dimensions, as numerous prior publications show that the scale measures a positive and affective mood dimension. Factor score loadings for each measure will be back projected for each subject. These will then be analyzed as dependent variables in separate linear regression models (one per factor score), with total days in isolation, isolation severity (mental and physical), age, and gender as predictor variables. Statistical significance will be assessed for the overall model and for individual regressors will be set at alpha criterion p > 0.01.

Analysis of Crisis Expectations
Here we will explore how expectations about the crisis evolve over the course of self-isolation, whether expectations shape mood and well-being, and if these effects depend in part on intolerance of uncertainty. To explore the influence of crisis expectations on mood and well-being, we will calculate both average expectations and difference scores (Δ-expectation, time 1 - time 6) for each category of expectations. Paired-samples t-tests will be used to compare pre vs post expectations, revealing any increase or decrease in their magnitude. We will also fit a repeated measures ANOVA with factors of time and modality to both average and Δ-expectations, to test for any shift in expectations from time 1 to time 6 between and across z-scored expectation modalities. To summarize the magnitude of shifts in mood (Δ-mood), a ‘baseline to peak’ measure will be calculated as the absolute difference between the mood score at time zero and the peak absolute mood score, separately for positive and negative affect dimensions. We will perform several exploratory analyses with these data; 1) exploration of correlations between Δ-expectation and average confidence 2) correlations between Δ-expectation and Δ-mood, and 3) exploratory mediation analyses asking if intolerance of uncertainty scores mediate the relationship of Δ-expectation and Δ-mood. All of these analyses will be subject to a p < 0.01 alpha criterion. 

Exploratory Multivariate Longitudinal Modelling
We will fit exploratory latent change score models (LCSM) expressing multivariate patterns of longitudinal changes in mood (PANAS-SF), depression (PHQ-9), and anxiety (STAI-SF), and isolation experience (C4, C5). These will be used to assess how dimensional patterns of association within and between these variables change over the 15 day period. A similar analysis approach will be used for measuring dynamic changes in mood and interoceptive experience, fitting a Latent Growth Models to each of the six ‘waves’ (timepoints) together.

q18.value: For any linear models, assumptions of normality will be checked using histograms, qq-plots, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported.

q19.value: These are described in our analyses plan. In general our minimum alpha-criterion for any test will be p < 0.01. In cases where multiple statistical tests are used per research question, these will be corrected using Bonferroni or false-discovery rate corrections, as described in the analysis plan.

q22.value:
Additional Exploratory Analyses
This project is inherently exploratory; no one in our lifetime has experienced an event such as the COVID-19 pandemic. We have endeavoured here to list common-sense analyses assessing the overall change in mood, mental-health, and interoception as a function of days in isolation and severity of isolation. However, there is a high likelihood that additional analyses of interest will arise, either proposed by students in our lab, or by the community. We also intend to write blog posts exploring the data; these will consist solely of data visualization and will not make strong inferences about the effects in the absence of full data collection. In all scientific communications, any exploratory or additional analyses will be clearly demarcated as such. Further, any deviations from these analyses will be noted. Where possible, we will pre-register future re-analyses of these data, for example as part of student projects or similar.

registration_responses.q2:
Subjective stress, negative well-being, negative mood/affect, and the intensity of interoceptive experience will all linearly increase as a function of isolation duration. 

Subjective interoceptive attention will decrease as a function of days since “country lockdown” for clinicians working directly with COVID-19 patients. I.e. The sign of the slope will be opposite than for people in isolation.

The magnitude of these increases will correlate with trait-level interoceptive belief, as measured by MIAI-2 subscales.

Intolerance of Uncertainty will significantly moderate the relationship of subjective anxiety/stress/mood and interoceptive attention. I.e, the more you are intolerant of uncertainty, the more you try to control the situation by attending to the body, and this results in increased negative affect. 

The magnitude and degree of shift in expectations about the crisis (e.g., its duration and severity) will correlate with intolerance of uncertainty, and will predict mood volatility.
registration_responses.q3: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q11: New participants will be admitted into the study for a total period of 30 days from the initial start date. We will attempt to recruit as many participants as possible within this time period. Based on our power analysis, we hope to recruit a minimum of 350 participants. However, given the inherently exploratory nature of this project, the multivariate design, and the implications for public health, we believe it is important to obtain as much data as possible. No data will be collected following the 30 day period, and we will not base any data collection decisions on results or analyses.
registration_responses.q12: We intend to analyze multivariate correlations between longitudinal changes in mood, affect, well-being, and interoceptive belief as a function of days in isolation. Our partially repeated measures design will improve power to detect the effect of days in isolation on these measures. However, we also want to build models expressing covariation between these effects, and individual differences in interoceptive belief, demographic variables, and respective isolation experience. Our chosen pre-existing measures have all been shown to have reasonably high consistency (e.g., Chronbachs alpha > 0.70) in norming samples. Although power-analysis for an exploratory design such as this is not obvious, we would like to be able detect significant effects explaining at least 5% or more of shared variance between our measures. According to the Gpower tool, to detect a coefficient of determination of 0.05, i.e. an effect size of r = 0.22, with 95% at a p < 0.01 alpha criterion in a two-tailed test requires 342 participants in a simple bivariate correlation model.
registration_responses.q13: Our stopping rule is that we will stop collecting data (admitting new participants) after 30 days of data collection.
registration_responses.q18: For any linear models, assumptions of normality will be checked using histograms, qq-plots, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported.

registration_responses.q6.question: The study will apply a repeated measures observational design. Participants recruited from the web and online participant pools will be invited to complete 6 total surveys, once every 72 hours, over a period of 15 days. These will include measures of mood, affect, anxiety, depression, and interoceptive experience. Additionally, they will fill out demographic and situational information about themselves and their experience of the COVID-19 pandemic. Semi-daily measures of mood and interoceptive experience will be sampled by short online rating scales, delivered once every 72 hours.
registration_responses.q10.question: All measurements will be conducted via the Aarhus University Redcap system, which has been previously approved by the Danish Data Protection Act and is fully GDPR compliant. Participants will receive a sign-up link directing them to an initial survey which will provide information about the study and require informed consent prior to participating. Following the completion of the first measure, they will receive automated emails every 72 hours, at the same time as they completed the first survey session. These emails will contain a link directing them to the survey measures for that day. A total of 6 measurements will be obtained, with the majority occurring on session 1 (day 1) and session 6 (day 16). A total of 145 measures will be collected at time 1, 127 at time 6, and 32 at times 2-5. See figure 1 for overview.

registration_responses.q17.question:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable. 

Mental Health 
Summary scores of well-being (WHO-5), depression (PHQ-9), anxiety (STAI-7), the sense of agency (Rotter-12), and intolerance of uncertainty will be measured by summing individual item responses according to their published standards. Paired sample t-tests will be used to compare time 1 vs time 2 scores for each of these measures.  Additionally, Pearson correlations between paired differences on each measure and the total time in isolation (continuous variable) will be calculated. A bonferroni corrected alpha threshold of p < 0.005 will be used to assess statistical significance for these 10 comparisons. 

Experience with Social Distancing
One-way repeated measures ANOVAs will be used to analyze linear increase or decreases in how much people report worrying about the crisis (C4), the strength of their social distancing measures (C5), and their mental and physical isolation tolerance (ES2 & ES3). The F-test on the main effect of time will be used to evaluate any significant linear change on these variables, alpha criterion p < 0.01. Exploratory correlations between these measures and the previously described pre vs post shifts in mental health scores will be calculated; this exploratory analysis will use an alpha criterion P < 0.005 to assess significance. 

Timepoint 1 Experience Sampling Data
Initial responses to the mood and interoceptive experience sampling data will be analyzed using an exploratory factor analysis approach. MIES data will be reduced using exploratory factor analysis, with varimax factor rotation and parallel analysis to determine the optimally fitting  number of factors. For PANAS-SF, we will constrain the factors to two total dimensions, as numerous prior publications show that the scale measures a positive and affective mood dimension. Factor score loadings for each measure will be back projected for each subject. These will then be analyzed as dependent variables in separate linear regression models (one per factor score), with total days in isolation, isolation severity (mental and physical), age, and gender as predictor variables. Statistical significance will be assessed for the overall model and for individual regressors will be set at alpha criterion p > 0.01.

Analysis of Crisis Expectations
Here we will explore how expectations about the crisis evolve over the course of self-isolation, whether expectations shape mood and well-being, and if these effects depend in part on intolerance of uncertainty. To explore the influence of crisis expectations on mood and well-being, we will calculate both average expectations and difference scores (Δ-expectation, time 1 - time 6) for each category of expectations. Paired-samples t-tests will be used to compare pre vs post expectations, revealing any increase or decrease in their magnitude. We will also fit a repeated measures ANOVA with factors of time and modality to both average and Δ-expectations, to test for any shift in expectations from time 1 to time 6 between and across z-scored expectation modalities. To summarize the magnitude of shifts in mood (Δ-mood), a ‘baseline to peak’ measure will be calculated as the absolute difference between the mood score at time zero and the peak absolute mood score, separately for positive and negative affect dimensions. We will perform several exploratory analyses with these data; 1) exploration of correlations between Δ-expectation and average confidence 2) correlations between Δ-expectation and Δ-mood, and 3) exploratory mediation analyses asking if intolerance of uncertainty scores mediate the relationship of Δ-expectation and Δ-mood. All of these analyses will be subject to a p < 0.01 alpha criterion. 

Exploratory Multivariate Longitudinal Modelling
We will fit exploratory latent change score models (LCSM) expressing multivariate patterns of longitudinal changes in mood (PANAS-SF), depression (PHQ-9), and anxiety (STAI-SF), and isolation experience (C4, C5). These will be used to assess how dimensional patterns of association within and between these variables change over the 15 day period. A similar analysis approach will be used for measuring dynamic changes in mood and interoceptive experience, fitting a Latent Growth Models to each of the six ‘waves’ (timepoints) together.

attributes.title: EFFECTIVENESS OF MOBILE LINE APPLICATION IN OBESITY PREVENTION THROUGH REGULAR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND HEALTHY EATING BEHAVIOR AMONG OVERWEIGHT WOMEN OF THAILAND: A RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRAIL
Effect of APOE polymorphism on cognition and brain in the CamCAN cohort
attributes.description: Polymorphisms in the Apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene have been associated with individual differences in cognition, brain structure and brain function. For example, the ε4 allele has been associated with cognitive and brain impairment in old age and increased risk of dementia, while the ε2 allele has been claimed to be neuroprotective. According to the “antagonistic pleiotropy” hypothesis, these polymorphisms have different effects across the lifespan, with ε4 for example postulated to confer benefits on cognitive and brain functions earlier in life. Using the rich cognitive and brain measures in the CamCAN cohort (www.cam-can.org), we will investigate the “antagonistic pleiotropy” hypothesis by testing for allele-by-age interactions in approximately 600 people from across the adult lifespan (18-88 years), on six outcome variables related to cognition, brain structure and brain function (fluid intelligence, verbal memory, hippocampal gray matter volume, mean diffusion within white matter, and resting-state connectivity measured by both functional magnetic resonance imaging and magnetoencephalography).

attributes.title: Labelless Self Bias
attributes.description: Self bias, seen in perceptual matching tasks, has been found to be stable across many settings. However, questions have been raised as to whether this is due to the label present. Therefore, is self bias seen in a perceptual matching task without labels?

q1.value: Does the self prioritisation effect occur in label-less perceptual matching tasks?

q3.value: Strong evidence shows that the self prioritisation effect (faster and more accurate responses to information related to the self) is stable and present across a variety of perceptual matching tasks. However, recent studies have shown that the labels used may be driving this bias.  Therefore, we will measure the self prioritisation effect in perceptual matching task without the use of labels. Participants will learn pairings of colour and shapes that will represent themselves, a friend and stranger and later judge whether pairings shown are the same as those learnt. This will explore whether the self prioritisation effect is found when all familiarity with stimuli is removed.

q4.value:
The self prioritisation effect will be seen, faster reaction time and greater accuracy will be seen in pairings associated with the self when compared to a friend and stranger.

Explore prioritisation in mismatch trials as it is unknown whether self-related stimuli will lead to prioritisation or whether the interaction between self factors and neutral factors may lead to competition and inhibit prioritisation
